Message.Title: Hey Obama, Hey Geithner!
Message.Msg: Here's what your proposal to Boner and McCONnell really SHOULD have said: (1) Top marginal income tax rates go up by ~4% -- unless CONs complain, in which case they go up by 20% instead. =D (2) Tax income from capital gains, which IS a form of INCOME after all, at the SAME rates as you tax income a worker earns by the sweat of his/her back or brow. (3) Tax "unrealized" capital gains during the tax year in which they actually occur, NOT years or decades later ... or (with the stepped-up basis rules at death) NEVER. (4) Make income from capital gains subject to FICA withholdings to exactly the same extent as "sweat" income from work. (5) Do away with FICA income cap. (6) Phase out deductions on high-income taxpayers. (Oh yeah... Way to go, Mitt. GOOD IDEA!) (7) Means test social safety net benefits. (8) Stop the boondoggle of allowing charitable contribution of appreciated capital assets (i.e. those with built-in capital gain) WITHOUT triggering a "realization" event. [NOTE - (7) is much less important, arguably unnecessary, if (2) is actually passed.] (9) NO MORE "COST PLUS" GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS. EVER. PERIOD. (10) Medicare/Medicaid/Obamacare free to negotiate volume discounts with pharmaceutical, medical device and medical services providers. (11) Estate taxes go back to pre-Dubya levels, or mebbe just a wee bit higher...

Topic.Title: Hey Obama, Hey Geithner!

Message.Msg: A Government Accountability Office study in 2000, when the price gap was larger than it is today, found the sugar program cost consumers nearly $2 billion in some years. If world prices fall again — and the Organisation of Economic Co-operation and Development forecasts that they will — U.S. prices will stay high, thanks to the import quotas. American consumers will again be paying a billion or two in hidden taxes that go straight to the bottom of line of big sugar growers. … Sugar program defenders, like Debbie Stabenow, D-Mich., chairwoman of the Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry, are correct that the sugar program creates sugar-growing jobs here in the U.S., but the Commerce Department estimated that for every sugar-grower job gained, three other jobs are lost. … But the lobby for the sugar program is strong. Most famously, the Fanjul family in Florida, owner of Florida Crystals, are deeply embedded in Washington politics. Over the last three elections, the Fanjuls have given more than $1.8 million to federal candidates and political action committees, according to data from the Center for Responsive Politics.

Message.Title: Rhonda's right wing friends
Message.Msg: woopsie Hungarian MP Marton Gyongyosi has been condemned for reportedly calling for a survey to count the number of Jews in Hungary, especially in parliament and government, "because they pose a security threat". The deputy, from the right wing Jobbik party, is said to have made the remarks on Monday during a debate on the Middle East in the Hungarian parliament. Jobbik is the third largest block from Hungary in the European parliament with three MEPs, having attained almost 15 per cent of the vote in European elections in 2009.

As Norquist read aloud a transcript of Chambliss’s earlier remarks, item by item, Norquist recalled later, the senator repeatedly assured him on each one that he didn’t mean to imply they had major differences when it came to GOP principles on taxes. “He said he’d wished he hadn’t invoked my name and wished that he’d been clearer,” Norquist recalled from the Monday conversation. Norquist said he came away from the conversation with this understanding of Chambliss’s position: “If he’d get a jillion dollars of spending cuts, he’d be willing to get rid of a deduction or two.”
